Package com.rb.nonbiz.testmatchers

Class RBValueMatchers

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.testmatchers.RBValueMatchers
public class RBValueMatchers
extends java.lang.Object
Test infrastructure for comparing primitive values using TypeSafeMatchers.

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors
    Constructor Description
    RBValueMatchers()

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    static org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<java.math.BigDecimal> bigDecimalMatcher​(java.math.BigDecimal expected, Epsilon epsilon)  
    static <T> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<java.lang.Class<T>> classMatcher​(java.lang.Class<T> expected)  
    static org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<java.lang.Double> doubleAlmostEqualsMatcher​(double expected, Epsilon epsilon)  
    static <V extends java.lang.Enum<? super V>>
    org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<V>    		 enumMatcher​(V expected)
    Only added for extra clarity; the same functionality could be obtained using typeSafeEqualTo().
    static <T> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> epsilonForNumericsElseEqualityMatcher​(T expected, Epsilon epsilon)
    For any two objects, performs an epsilon comparison if both are numeric (implement Number), otherwise just tests for equality.
    static org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<java.lang.Float> floatAlmostEqualsMatcher​(float expected, float epsilon)
    Although by now (Dec 2022) we have a specialized ImpreciseValue subclass to denote an epsilon, the case of float is special and rare enough that we don't need a float version of Epsilon.

    static org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<java.lang.String> stringMatcher​(java.lang.String expected)
    Although we can just use typeSafeEqualTo with strings, sometimes it's convenient to use this, because for strings that are very long, sometimes it's easier to debug any differences by looking at the index of the first difference by putting a breakpoint below.

    hamcrest provides an equalTo, but it's a plain Matcher, not a TypeSafeMatcher
    static <T> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> typeSafeSame​(T expected)

    • impreciseValueMatcher

      public static <V extends ImpreciseValue<? super V>> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<V> impreciseValueMatcher​(V expected, Epsilon epsilon)

    • rbNumericValueMatcher

      public static <T extends RBNumeric<? super T>> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> rbNumericValueMatcher​(T expected, Epsilon epsilon)

    • doubleAlmostEqualsMatcher

      public static org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<java.lang.Double> doubleAlmostEqualsMatcher​(double expected, Epsilon epsilon)

    • floatAlmostEqualsMatcher

      public static org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<java.lang.Float> floatAlmostEqualsMatcher​(float expected, float epsilon)
      Although by now (Dec 2022) we have a specialized ImpreciseValue subclass to denote an epsilon, the case of float is special and rare enough that we don't need a float version of Epsilon.

    • numberMatcher

      public static <T extends java.lang.Number> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> numberMatcher​(T expected, Epsilon epsilon)
      Matches two different Number objects. It will match if e.g. it's 11.0 (double) and 11 (int). We use this with JsonObject because it's not always easy to specify the exact numeric types in our test data. Also see strictWithTypesNumberMatcher(T, T)

    • integerValueMatcher

      public static <T extends IntegerValue<T>> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> integerValueMatcher​(T expected)

    • strictWithTypesNumberMatcher

      public static <T extends java.lang.Number> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> strictWithTypesNumberMatcher​(T expected, T epsilon)
      Matches two different Number objects, but will not match if e.g. it's 11.0 (double) and 11 (int). Also see numberMatcher(T, com.rb.nonbiz.types.Epsilon)

    • enumMatcher

      public static <V extends java.lang.Enum<? super V>> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<V> enumMatcher​(V expected)
      Only added for extra clarity; the same functionality could be obtained using typeSafeEqualTo().

    • stringMatcher

      public static org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<java.lang.String> stringMatcher​(java.lang.String expected)
      Although we can just use typeSafeEqualTo with strings, sometimes it's convenient to use this, because for strings that are very long, sometimes it's easier to debug any differences by looking at the index of the first difference by putting a breakpoint below.

    • typeSafeEqualTo

      public static <T> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> typeSafeEqualTo​(T expected)
      hamcrest provides an equalTo, but it's a plain Matcher, not a TypeSafeMatcher

    • typeSafeSame

      public static <T> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> typeSafeSame​(T expected)
      hamcrest provides #same, but it's a plain Matcher, not a TypeSafeMatcher

    • typeSafeAlwaysTrue

      public static <T> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> typeSafeAlwaysTrue()

    • classMatcher

      public static <T> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<java.lang.Class<T>> classMatcher​(java.lang.Class<T> expected)

    • epsilonForNumericsElseEqualityMatcher

      public static <T> org.hamcrest.TypeSafeMatcher<T> epsilonForNumericsElseEqualityMatcher​(T expected, Epsilon epsilon)
      For any two objects, performs an epsilon comparison if both are numeric (implement Number), otherwise just tests for equality.
